titleStmt.title: working group discussion on the timing of the implementation of joint degree programs
titleStmt.funder: VOICE is funded by FWF, the Austrian Science Fund (Project No. L448)

publicationStmt.publisher: Barbara Seidlhofer, Stefan Majewski, Ruth Osimk-Teasdale, Marie-Luise Pitzl, Michael Radeka
publicationStmt.distributor: VOICE Project, University of Vienna, Austria

availability.p: The Vienna-Oxford International Corpus of English (VOICE) was created by Barbara Seidlhofer (project director) and Angelika Breiteneder, Theresa Klimpfinger, Stefan Majewski, Marie-Luise Pitzl (project researchers). VOICE POS XML 2.0 is the first part-of-speech tagged version of VOICE. It is based on the same data source as VOICE 2.0 XML. VOICE 2.0 XML, which includes minor revisions with regard to previous versions, and VOICE POS XML 2.0, are available for download at the VOICE Project's website http://www.univie.ac.at/voice/ under a Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial-ShareAlike 3.0 Unported (CC BY-NC-SA 3.0) License (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc-sa/3.0/). The original audio files are held at the Department of English, University of Vienna. 23 selected audio files are available as audio streams in the VOICE Online interface at the VOICE Project's website http://www.univie.ac.at/voice.
The recommended citation for VOICE POS XML 2.0 is:

p.bibl: VOICE. 2013. The Vienna-Oxford International Corpus of English (version POS XML 2.0 ). Director: Barbara Seidlhofer; Researchers: Stefan Majewski, Ruth Osimk-Teasdale, Marie-Luise Pitzl, Michael Radeka, Nora Dorn.

availability.p: The short citation for VOICE POS XML 2.0 is:

p.bibl: VOICE. 2013. The Vienna-Oxford International Corpus of English (version POS XML 2.0).

availability.p: For further information about availability and copyright permissions, please see the README file included in the download package. For further enquiries please contact the VOICE Project at voice@univie.ac.at.

notesStmt.note: This working group discussion involves representatives from several European universities. The discussion happens during a longer workshop which focuses on creating joint degrees and establishing cooperation among universities in Europe. S1 is the chairperson, but has only been asked to chair the discussion a couple of minutes before. Initially, S1 and the participants are not sure which issues they should address in their discussion. After a few minutes, S6, who is a high official of [org1] but does not participate in this working group, enters the room. S1 asks him about the particular task of their working group. S6 explains that he wants them to determine the temporal sequence of previously collected questions, then he leaves the group again. S1 organizes the group, asks S7 to take notes and act as rapporteur. The group starts discussing the order of the questions in a joint document. The speakers also mention and elaborate on many related issues.

equipment.p: Portable minidisc recorder with electret condenser stereo microphone

namespace.name: http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0
namespace.tagUsage: Used to mark a stretch of speech commonly preceded and followed by a pause or by a change of speaker. A u is, however, not required to be bounded by a pause or a change of speaker, nor does it represent a turn in a conversation analytic sense. At a minimum, a u is some phonetic production or noise made by a given speaker or a group of speakers.

Used to mark lexical forms (tokens), but also word fragments, pauses, onomatopoeic noises, spelling, laughter and breathing. w is used with ana and lemma attributes to mark its part-of-speech and lemma. Note that for tokens with ambiguous tags w may contain nested w elements to express alternative interpretations.
